section.heading: Argument of Homer S. Durden, Jr.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- Campbell, Commissioner of Agriculture of the State of Georgia et al., Appellants, versus William Hussey, Jr., et al.
Mr. Durden, you may continue your argument.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you Mr Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) you were saying just as we wrote yesterday that the presence of the blue ticket and the white ticket on a basket of tobacco meant that the basket sold for a lower price.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct sir.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But they didn't explain why that is true?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Frankly sir, I don't know unless we go back to the tobacco Act, Federal Tobacco Inspection Act in 1935, the Federal Act, where Congress stated that without uniform standards of classification and inspection, the evaluation of tobacco is susceptible to manipulation, control, and speculation and for that reason, it was necessary to have regulation by a single authority.
Otherwise, you have undue fluctuations in price which would impose an undue burden on interstate commerce for the sale of tobacco.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But the Federal Act doesn't regulate price, does it?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Oh no.

But the -- where you have dual regulation and we have for the Federal Act identifying tobacco in one amount and the Georgia Act identified in a different manner, the conflict is what led to what Congress said would happen undue fluctuations in price and I think that that Congress was -- you might say looking in a crystal ball and see and that this would happen, it did happen just like you said it would.
Have I answered the question sir?

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Is this -- any of this in the record?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: That was put in part of the Federal Act, sir.

Now, Mr. Cohn is going to handle the part of the case pertaining to the preemption by the Federal Government and in his brief and argument, he goes into the congressional record and to debate from the floor of Congress where these Congressmen expressed their feelings about the very point that you mentioned sir.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I can understand the difference in putting a blue tag and a white tag on, but why would that make any difference to the buyers of the big tobacco companies when they see the same constituencies and they know what the score is, why would they knock down 18 dollars a hundred on the same tobacco simply because it had a blue tag on it, rather than a white one?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Again, I was speculating sir.
It's not in the record.
We have no proof, but we have a condition in our tobacco growers where we have a huge number of growers with a small number of purchasers.
Those tobacco buyers know that where a man hauls his tobacco 400 or 500 miles to the market to sell it that he more or less has to take what they want to give him for it.
It would be prohibited for him to turn the sale down.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: It does take it home.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: That's right sir.
On the tobacco sales, the sale amount of tobacco is being sold, the floor man would put on the sheet the price and the purchaser's name or seller.
If I follow to that sale and I was not satisfied with that price, I would turn that sale by turning right there.
When I tear that tag that means that I'm dissatisfied with the price.
I can then take my tobacco up and carry it by home.
But if I haul it 400 or 500 miles, I can't.
It -- it'd be prohibited.
So they realize that they get offer me whatever they want and I more or less got to take it unless I live locally where I can turn it and bring it back and resell it tomorrow.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: But why couldn't that happen whether the basket had a blue tag or a white tag?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: It could happen sir except for the fact that the blue tag is spotted as being -- tobacco has been hauled a long distance and they know just like when I use to have to haul my tobacco a 100 to 150 miles to South Georgia, I -- I would have to take a price a lot of times but I didn't want because I couldn't hold it back to my home and put it on market another time.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I guess there's no doubt that the one or another as I gather you argument in that case, the buyers do not want to pay as much for the South Carolina Tobacco as they do for the other.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: They do sir.
They will, and they did assign --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: No but as I gathered from what you said, I'm just trying to get --

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- the exact import of, they will not pay you that because it has a blue tag, and a blue tag signifies to them that it's coming from somewhere 400 or 500 miles and that has to be one of the Carolina.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: That's right sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They won't buy.

Now, may I ask you -- because of your familiarity with tobacco, I have a recollection that -- that tobacco grown in Connecticut, that suppose at least by Connecticut people, do you want to know the best tobacco in the world by purposes to which they used it?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I may be wrong to that state but I believe it is, it is Connecticut.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Connecticut does grow tobacco, yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, what is required with references -- against the regulation for them to stamp that, has made and grown in Connecticut?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Oh, sir that is a different type of tobacco, we are --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand -- I understand that.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: We're -- we're dealing streaker or flue-cured tobacco.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I -- I understand that.
But what I'm asking you is do you know whether the regulations permit them to label that as Connecticut Tobacco, on the basis that it is a different country?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: I don't know, sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You don't know?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: I don't -- I'm -- (Voice Overlap) flue-cured tobacco now.
We have burley.
We have air-and-sun, fire-cured and various types of tobacco and in my section of the country we grew flue-cure tobacco only.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But I get -- it's frequently I see oranges (Inaudible) grown in (Inaudible) grown in California or grown in --

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- Florida?
Do you know whether that is in line with the Government's regulations or did they forget that?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: As long as it does not undue to burden interstate commerce, it's -- it's perfectly alright.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yeah, what I am talking about the Federal Government, does it forbid that?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: No.
Not that I know of.

So far as I know, there is nothing in federal statute, I -- I could -- could be mistaken in this, pertaining to citrus fruits, the appellant cited the cases Sligh versus Kirkwood which is a Florida case, ruled that of Florida statute, where Florida passed an act in making a criminal offense to shift from the state of Florida any citrus fruits one-fifth for human consumption and this Court in passing on that case, pointed out that they could do that, that to restrict their local in character and that the Federal Government had not acted to --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's the point.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: On the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There's no federal statute.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: No federal statute and of course for that particular statute did not restrict, identify or do anything to citrus fruits in California, citrus fruits in Texas or any other state.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In fact, it does refer to citrus fruits, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Sir?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They do have a statute which gives the same agency considerable regulatory power over citrus fruits?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: That was Florida, for citrus fruit grown in Florida.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I recall also getting some other states.
They advertise variant astringents that they grow in Sun Valley, some other states, Texas -- pink grapefruit.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: All I'm trying to get at is that the general custom if you know it.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Well, we -- we -- we ship peaches from Georgia, Georgia peaches.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I recall that too.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Georgia eggs.
As a matter of fact, we ship Georgia poultry, but so long as it does not unduly burden interstate commerce, that's -- that's permissible.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) but the question is of course whether the collision as I understand it --

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) the federal statute.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: But if I put all my citrus fruit, anything that would place in embargo on citrus fruit from other states, I can't do it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I see two different questions as Justice Black has pointed out namely the power of a State in the protection of health or even the protection of its local economy to make provisions protecting health and furthering the local economy and charged to be in conflict with the commerce clause.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's why I am intrigued, that's a very different problem from --

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- the one whether it's a matter of construction, there is a collision.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: I see.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that's our question here, isn't it?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir.
We -- we say that the Georgia Act was not local in character.
They placed an embargo on products brought in from Carolina.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You would have a very different question if there were no Federal Tobacco Act.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the same Georgia statute.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: You probably wouldn't be here.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: No, in fact, I would either.
But --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Durden, is there any -- is there any issue in this case as to the relative merits of the -- of this fruit type of tobacco that is grown in Georgia, and Alabama and the new so called New Belt on the one hand and that -- and that grown in the Carolina's or the other?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Maybe I can explain it to you Mr. Chief Justice in this way.

The appellants had a Doctor Sean, I believe what's his name, who is an agronomist from the Clinton Collage, he's a tobacco specialist and he explained to the trail court, that farther up the Belt you get the different nicotine content that you'd find in tobacco as a general rule.
Now there is -- there is no set rule.
In other words, I could plant ten hectares tobacco on my farm.
One side of my field, I'd have a light sandy lawn soil.
The other side, I have what we call a tipped and red pebble soil.
Well, the chemical characteristics and probably the nicotine content for the tobacco grown in the sandy lawn would be different from other.
There is no uniformity sir.
It's for that reason that this tobacco is aged for about three years after it's bought in the market.

Then as in this huge (Inaudible), then the chemist of the tobacco company, when they start of manufacture that into cigarette, they have to get in a sample of tobacco because you may have (Inaudible) tobacco just grown on 50 different falls.
And they take that tobacco and run that chemical analysis on the samples to see what must be added so that, they were getting uniformity of taste.

As you know, when you light up a cigarette, you smoke as one cigarette or one cigar, of course we're not dealing with cigar tobacco, which you smoke one cigarette because it has a taste that you like.
And when you light that cigarette, you expect to have the same taste that the previous cigarette that same brand have, so they must have uniformity.
And in order to get that uniformity, they run this chemical test to see what must be added to that tobacco.
And they add licorice, now honey, and the other flavors that make a Camel cigarette taste like Lucky Strike or Phillip Morris to get that uniformity.
So, there is -- there is nothing that you can say that is uniformed by tobacco.
It's -- you might say almost to carry an agent for this attitude -- added ingredients.
And each brand of cigarette has a certain percentage of what we call the premium grade tobacco and it also had a certain percentage of your rough trash you might say.
No one is monopolizing the -- cream of the crop you might say, but they -- they blend that.
It's a blend is what it is.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: There must have been some reason though when they auctioneer cane to the first row, in the first basket with that had a blue tag on it, there were no bids at all.
Maybe it's not in the record; maybe it's not important, I'm just curious.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Maybe I can answer this question.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In answering that, would you state who hires the auctioneer?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: The Warehouse.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: The particular warehouse --

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- in the community, they have in (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Well most of our warehouse sir, live in Carolina because they come that far with short seller state.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But do not represent particular consumers --

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Oh no --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- wholesale consumers (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: No, you may have one auctioneer that would work for two different warehousemen.
He -- he is an employee by the warehousemen.
He gets a certain amount of each basket of tobacco he auctions on.
Your question sir, I don't know and I -- and I don't have the proof of why that first basket of tobacco sold for $61 a hundred pound.
And then when it realized that every blue tag tobacco, they refused to buy it at any products.
As you recall yesterday, I made the statement, that as soon as that buyer realized that it was a blue tag tobacco and he turned to the warehousemen, “I can't buy,” why, because it's blue tag.”

The next buyer (Inaudible) order, too much moisture content the he said, “Yes that's right” and it was at that point that we stopped the sale and had the Government grader to come back and regrade that part of tobacco.
And he regraded it, certified that it's in good order and we tried to sell it and we couldn't sell it.
Basket after basket after that, they refused to bid anything on blue tag tobacco.
Now, it has been stipulated that as much as $18 a 100 difference in the price of blue tag tobacco and the white tag tobacco.
On the first --

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Now, that's in price -- that's in price but not value.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Right.
Also, the (Inaudible) grade of Carolina tobacco by the Government grade, sold for less and identical grade of Carolina -- or Georgia tobacco until the blue tags are removed.

And the record will show that after the first two days, when we got a restraining order, when the Judge Collet signed a preliminary restraining order and the blue tags were removed that the Carolina tobacco sold right on par with the Georgia tobacco.
The price disparity disappeared.
They can no longer pick it out.
I wish I had the evidence sir, to answer your question.

I don't have it, but it is another case of where you have a huge number of producers with a small number of purchasers and it could very easily work into collusion, control, speculation and manipulation just as Congress said.
Now, we were selling to thousands of tobacco buyers.
I don't think we'd be here today.
I'm not accusing the tobacco companies or anything, I'm guessing, it's a must.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Tell me were any of these marketing facts involved of the adoption of the federal regulations (Inaudible) that makes the counsel more aggressive.
Do you think that you're talking about now was -- do they underlie some of the federal regulations, these facts of marketing tobacco?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir, yes sir.
I think Mr. Cohn could possible go to that better.
I'd be glad going to if you would like but we --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: No, no if you have answered yes then I willing to (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: That -- that was surely congressional record that he has.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Durden, may I ask you just one more question?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Do these buyers have the competence to walk along the road that you told us about and -- and from their observation while they re buying be able to determine this came from Georgia, this came from Alabama, this came from the Carolinas?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: No --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- is that within the field of their company?

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: They cannot.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: They cannot.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: And as a matter of fact sir, well Mr. Chief Justice, I see my time has expired --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: -- may I answer the question?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, you -- you take a couple of minutes more.

turn.speaker: homer_s_durden_jr
turn.label: Mr. Homer S. Durden, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you sir.
At the trial in this case before the three-judge federal court, I had my client go into warehouse and pull five samples of tobacco.
Two of those samples were taken from a pile of Carolina tobacco.
Three of those samples were taken from pile of Georgia tobacco that the government grader has said was the identical grade as far as the Government was concerned.
As I recall, they were grade B foil.
I could be wrong on that.

Every witness, including the warehousemen that we represented, the specialist in Clinton College, the Mr. Nutz who was the representative for the Universal Tobacco Company, we would ask them to pick out which tobacco came in Carolina, which tobacco came from Georgia.
They could not do it.

Now, the reason they couldn't do it so, most of this tobacco that we've grown, see the grown and gathered it in North Carolina and carried to South Georgia where it's planted in plant beds in the early December.
Those have to be kept under can, tobacco (Inaudible) and all up along in March, these commercial plant growers sell their plants.
They own up five or six inches high.
In the fall the buyers of those plants transplants that tobacco.
I may buy a truck load of tobacco plants from that farmer, plant it on my farm, under the Georgia Act, that's Type 14 tobacco.

From that same plant bed, grown from their identical seed, a man from North Carolina may plant -- this type 13 or type 12 or type 11, according to where he happens to replant it, it is the same tobacco.
Tobacco is nothing but a weed.
Now, these experts are good.
They can come along on the sale and they can tell whether it's the looks or the (Inaudible) or the tips.
You see, tobacco stock has some 20-24 leaves.
The lower leaves, we call the sun leaves and they can examine those.
The government graded can examine it and tell you right quick.
It's a sun leaves.
Then we have our prime leaves which are the middle leaves and they can be -- the difference from those can be told and then we have our tips which are usually much small.
So they know the tobacco.
It stands the reason at this cigarette company with a millions of dollars invested, they have to know tobacco.
And if there was any difference in the Georgia grown tobacco and the Carolina tobacco, they would pick it out, but they're just not.
If there is no other question, my time has run out.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Cohn.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I wonder if you could take two minutes of your time to state explicitly and with as much detail as it's relevant just what the items of collision are between the Federal Act and its implementing regulations and the legislation which you say must fall because of the overriding authority of that body of federal law.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: The Federal Act Your Honor has as its prime purpose and it is set out in the act, it is set out in the legislative history, the creation of a uniform, classification, standard system of tobacco.
Now, the Act itself says, “Uniform standards for classification and inspection of tobacco, Section 2.”
They repeat it.

The legislative history is build up with -- with the controversy between the proponents of the Act who claim that uniform standards of classification were necessary and the opponents who said, “No, this is a local problem, leave it up to the States.”
Congress in adopting the Act, adopted the argument of the proponents, and in fact as I said, put it into the Act itself.

Now, the Secretary of Agriculture, under the authority granted him in the statute has established seven different classes of tobacco, the 27 different types, perhaps there's as many as 200 different grades et cetera down the line.

He has also said, that the tobacco of the identical -- the characteristics, the same quality, and length, and moisture and so on and so forth shall be type identically, no mater where it may have been grown by the accidents of geography.

In other words, the tobacco grown on one side in Savannah, the River, the tobacco grown on the other side, if it has the same characteristics physically, it will have the same type whether that'd be 14 or 13 or 12 or what have you.
Now, the State of Georgia -- I mean, we continue one more point.

The Act also has as its purpose not just the establishment of classification and standards in vacuum, but the communication of those standards to the buyer and the seller in order to bring some order to the chaos that range at -- ranged in the tobacco markets before 1935.

Legislative history is full of descriptions of the way this, as my friend said, “The thousands of the tobacco farmers were --” well the words -- the one Congressman was subject to the wholesale of robbery by the few buyers and speculators mainly because the farmer did not know what type and grade of tobacco he had.
The buyers had their own systems.
The farmers might have a system and there was just mass confusion.
The Congress, as I said, wanted this information of the classification of a particular lot tobacco to communicate to the buyer and the seller.
It gave authority for this to the Secretary.

The Secretary set forth two requirements for the communication, one, that the type and the grade, now not just the grade but the type and the grade it says in the regulations, be on the warehouse ticket that is on the basket then secondly, that the auctioneer when he begins the auction of a lot of tobacco shall to publicly announce this information, so that the buyers and the sellers know what they are dealing with.
That is the federal statute.
The state --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: All that def -- they're carrying out those two definitions as the type and grade, that's all pre-determined before the auction begins?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That is correct.
As I understand it, about an hour or so before the auction starts, one or more federal inspectors start to go down the road one-by-one.
There maybe one inspector to a small warehouse.

There maybe as many as three or five in a large warehouse and they inspect each basket of tobacco; they pull out different leaves from different -- different areas within the basket to get what they consider, a represented its sample.
And then they make this determination, what is the type, what is the grade?

Now, I might point out at this point that if an interest deportee, either the farmer or somebody who buys a tobacco is unhappy about the -- the typing and grading, he can ask the original inspector to re-inspect, to reclassify.
He can also call in that inspector's supervisor who is -- probably in the same warehouse if -- if not his in the same locality to re-inspect.

And finally, there is an appeal, the procedure to the Tobacco Division of Agriculture Department and they have the field offices with some one designated to do it so that there would be a day or maybe two days to lay that, but as you say, this is all done before the -- the actual auction.
At the time of the auction, this information is publicly announced.
Now, the Georgia has come in --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Before you get to that, may I ask you this question?
How -- how many types and grades Mr. Cohn did you say that --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- there are --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- had been classified by the Secretary of Agriculture?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: There are seven classes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Seven classes.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: There are 27 types --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: 27 types.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: They are -- well, I know in flue-cured, they are 168 different grades and somebody just told me that there are more in some other classes of tobacco.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: So I -- there are -- I will say upwards of 200 different grades.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) may I ask you this.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- you said seven classes, how many types?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: 27 types, at the present time.
Now, may I point out that this is subject to change --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- because as condition has been changed, the Secretary has amended his classifications from time to time.
I assume -- I'm sure it is done through (Inaudible) proceedings where anybody who's interested and come in and get his opinion as to what should be done.
At the moment, I am informed that the tobacco growers in Florida claimed they have entirely distinctive type and they wanted the CC from Georgia and have a type number 15 down there.
I understand this is under the consideration of agriculture now.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, may I pursue that just one --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Sure.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- one -- one more step?
When the Secretary does this, he classifies all of the tobaccos in America.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And if the Georgia law is permitted to stand that would leave us with it with one more grade or classification then the Secretary of Agriculture has set up.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: You will not only one more, but you would have a different one using the same terminology.
You would also have -- you -- all that Georgia has done here, and I want to point this out because I think it is very important.
All that Georgia has done here is to set up a definition for type number 14.
If they are permitted to do this, I see no legal distinction why they cannot come in and set up their own standard for 168 different grades for type 13, 12 and 11.
I -- I don't see why North Carolina can't do the same thing etcetera and etcetera, going right back to where we start it from 1935.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Does the Secretary of Agriculture publish market reports in accordance with those classifications?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: It does Your Honor.
In fact, there are price reports out, I believe every marketing day and their average is every week and there's a monthly report and well, you know what the department will publish.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes and of course that would apply only to the classifications he had made.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Are -- are all the differences indeed in the type and class of the differences in class, type, and grade, from seven to 27 to a hundred and something, are all those differences reflected in price?
Was it a choice of quality, a choice of preference within the same price grading, within the same price scheme?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I would say Your Honor, if I understand your question correctly --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) whether does it -- whether type class two, grade 30 --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and so on, the differences between the grade and the classes, the types and the grade, are those differences functioned to the price?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Well, it -- it may be in the sense that once the buyer and the seller knows what the type and grade is at a particular basket of tobacco.
Now, after all there are certainly impurely of grade, everybody agrees with that.
There is some controversy as to whether one type is better than another.
I -- I refuse to get into that, but the -- there are certainly impurely of grades.

There are grades that there are -- there's a tobacco that is water logged in which case it gets a certain grade or if it is too dry or if it's tore or what you have you, this all goes into the grading system.
So, once the buyer and seller know what the type and grade of tobacco is, they have the basis to bargain.
They know what they are getting, and they know what they are selling.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It may be -- he may decide to buy one grade out of another, because of sheer profit just one person may prefer -- one grade out to another although --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- of course it's the same or he may just make a preference of -- as a preference.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Well as my --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) grade relationship.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: As my brother here pointed out, in a cigarette, you have a blend, you have and if the Lucky Strike, the people -- pardon me, you have a large percentage of scrap that is your lowest grades.
Now, I would assume that there is a surging, a competitive supply, and the demand system on scrap.
If there is an enough scrap, the price of scrap will go up -- because they have to have it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: It's only been from classification that the Secretary has made both as the class -- as the class and as the type --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Type and grade.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- and grade has some rational basis for the making, is that right?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's correct Your Honor.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And that rational classification may even if it doesn't but it may affect the buyer and the seller.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's right.
It is intended too by Congress.
And --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And furthermore, it is intended to be uniformed throughout the country.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: And then what puzzles me is this.

According to the Secretary's classification the type as far as this Court (Inaudible) to your brief, as that type of flue-cured tobacco come, may know in the Southern Flue-cured or New Belt, Georgia, Florida, and Alabama, produced consequently in the Southern Section of Georgia and in some extent in Florida and Alabama, isn't?
How does the state definition differ?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: If you read this Mr. Justice Harlan, in vacuum, then I would agree word-for-word, there is no substantial difference, but you can't read it in vacuum.
It was not intended in vacuum, it is not applied in vacuum --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Alright, just to read (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I would now I like to draw your attention to page six.
Up near the top --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- of your brief?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Of the page, of my brief, where there is a definition of the term “types”.

And under that definition, this is about a third of the way -- way down, it says, “Tobacco which has the same characteristics and corresponding qualities, colors and length shall be treated as one type, regardless of any factors of historical or a geographic nature which cannot be determined from an -- an examination of the -- the tobacco.”
Now, there was a purpose for putting that in.
The purpose was pointed out by the Secretary when he first promulgated these regulations.
The Secretary said that it is not possible without a considerable detail, to specify all of the sections in which a certain type is produced, or to include all the local names.

He went on that in the present classification, now this is the first time he promulgated these -- these standards, in the present classification, it has been the purpose of the department to use a sufficient number of names to identify each type of tobacco, to supplement this information, the principal sections in which each type is produced are also shown.
In case, the local name of a type or the section in which it is produced is not covered under the description of the type, it does not follow that that the tobacco is of a different type.
The following rule will assist in determining the type in which any tobacco shall be placed and then he -- he quoted that -- the rule that I referred you to Your Honor.
Now, I set this out --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would you -- would you read that sentence.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- this is our --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- second batch.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: On page 23 --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) you might read.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- in case, the local --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: The 23 of my brief on top, the top line, in case, the local name of a type or the section in which it is produced is not covered under the description of the type, it does not follow that the tobacco is of a different type.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What disturbs me that is that here it is -- seems that this covered under the description of the type because you regulate, which Mr. Justice Harlan and all the judges described that time is being grown in three states particularly.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: But what this is saying Mr. Justice Black is that in the definition of Type 14, it would not be practical who list in every State in which it might possibly be grown.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Instead they have --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: -- but he says that if in case it's not done which indicates that he sometimes does it.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Does he do it for the reference with Connecticut tobacco?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's --- that right.
So that, if you have --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, there's nothing unusual about the saying of the types of consists of tobacco growing for the particular geographical areas.
Is it --?
-- is there anything unusual (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: But what this says is that the growing for that type is not necessarily limited to those geographic areas.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Unless -- unless you read, it is produced, here is the local name and type that is not covered under the description in type, but it is covered here.
That's what is bothering me.
May I ask you if you have been -- do you classify, is there anything that shows your practice has been to classify Carolina tobacco as Type 14?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Well, that is shown in the regulation which I refer to Mr. Justice Harlan --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- it is printed directly under that -- in that sentence which you -- you and I just have been --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- talking about, where it says, any tobacco, just -- just two lines down.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But you have -- I -- I -- remember that, but if you have already given a definition to a type which limits it to particular area, why would this general statement effect that special rule?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Because Your Honor, it was intended that the special rule that you call, be only the -- the naming of the principal places of production of that particular type.
If that particular type is grown elsewhere, and after all, you -- you can't tell from year -- for year what a farmer might -- might (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, one (Voice Overlap) was North Carolina and South Carolina tobaccos.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: It has been that when the inspector examines a lot of tobacco, he examines it for both the type and grade, and he says that, “This is Type 14” even though and it has grown in South Carolina.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Now, where does the record show that had been the fact here despite -- despite this regulation which points in my mind to the other direction?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: The record is on page.
Let me see if I can find it quickly here.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You know pardon me.
The reason I'm asking this is that -- I think it's nothing less common designating certain types for the purpose to buy, coming from a particular State.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Your -- Your Honor, may I make this clear --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there anything uncommon about that?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: No that's -- there is nothing uncommon about -- about designating any agriculture commodity from the State that it comes, but that's not this case.
If Georgia --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That's what -- that's what we have to decide.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- would here come in and say that we want all Georgia grown the tobacco, to have a label on it grown in Georgia, then we would have a different case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But suppose you include as a type, the question here is actually that whether that is a collision, suppose you include as a type and just said specifically Type 14 shall include all tobacco grown in South -- certain name, some kind of flue -- what is it?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Flue-cured.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Flue-cured tobacco, grown in South Georgia and Alabama and Florida, you'll include all that. That's all it said.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's -- that's right sir.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you mean that it would be -- it would conflict with that rule which you permit to identify as I suppose (Inaudible) where the only place have grown in those places that would somehow conflict constitutionally with your rule for the man -- for the people who grow the tobacco in those States put on that grown in those States.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: It would -- conflict if they say if Georgia says that tobacco grown Georgia only or for in Alabama, they're minor commodity, but if -- if -- if the Georgia comes in and says that tobacco sold in Georgia can be Type 14, only if it is grown in Georgia, Florida and Alabama, and not if it is this grown across the Savannah River.
What they have done to establish a different type --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm assuming -- I am assuming in my question which is an argued of the point.
I don't think it's been argued precisely on it much.
I'm assuming that your regulation says that the Type 14 is the type of tobacco, flue-cured tobacco grown in Georgia, Alabama and Florida.
That's all it said.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: If –

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Would you say that Georgia then would violate the constitution by a conflict with your regulation, if it said, “We want all on our tobacco grown in Georgia, Alabama and Florida.”

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I would say Your Honor--

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Even though -- even though that was a 100% in harmony with what the Board had done.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I would say that we, it wouldn't have a situation of conflict then but we would then have the problem of preemption and what the Georgia could act within this -- this area.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, I -- I don't suppose you'd called it preemption if they will finally help you to identify a type.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Was it in the Varnville case that Mr. Justice Brandeis said it was -- it was preemption, but that's --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Suppose it (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: But the -- the thing is Your Honor to know that the federal regulation is not as you have stated.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that's -- that's the -- that is impossible.
That's -- that's not one problem --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I mean I think that's not how it has been enforced (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) problem here which I was trying to find your view on assuming that it is, assuming if you specifically said as they argued and in your – (Inaudible) that you have limited Type 14 to tobacco grown on those three States, is it your position that we should hold a statute of Georgia unconstitutional which in addition to saying Type 14, says grown in Georgia, part of Alabama?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Here --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I know it is but -- but I want to find out what's your views.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I would say that the answer is yes sir --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: But I put that --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- because they used Type 14.
If they would only use grown in Georgia, then we would have a different situation.

But the fact is they have used a phrase the Type 14, which has a specific meaning in the (Inaudible) and what they are doing, even if they are coincidently -- even if they are assisting the Government and there are many cases -- I mean the Santa Fe Elevator case (Inaudible) and many others, where this -- this Court has said that where Congress has acted, the States cannot and assist.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could I put -- put that question for you a little bit.

Supposing Georgia had said, “We describe this tobacco in the very words of the federal regulation” according to page 8, but in addition, we want a blue tag to put on to make it easier to people to identify, would that come in to conflict with the federal regulation?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I would say there is no practical conflict.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: No what?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: There is no practical conflict, but there is this.
There is a different requirement on the warehousemen.
There is the fact that they are coming into an area on which Congress through its own and through the Secretary of Agriculture as the fully (Inaudible) I mean there's no argument there.
The -- the Townsend case was brought up yesterday as an -- an example where the Congress under -- of this Act did not preempt a field, but that was a different subject in Townsend.

But in this subject, the subject or classification and identification of the -- of the tobacco who -- and Congress through the Secretary of Agriculture has fully legislated and as this Court has stated many times that the State cannot come in even to the aid of Congress that they cannot make any additional or supplemental regulations.
The -- the Napier case where -- where the ICC through under the act of Congress prescribed certain matters as far as train, the local motive is concerned.
He said absolutely did nothing about a curtain on the -- on the cab.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Mr. Cohn, may I take you away from cases --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Sure, okay.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) finding out exactly what is case is about?
And I like to pursue Justice Black's questions.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: So that you don't make sub two things that are different namely, (1) that the state has added or subtracted or qualifed a requirement of federal law.
That's one problem.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And (2), a totally different problem even if the State had harmoniously supplemented the federal law may do so.

Now those are very different three -- very different questions and what I want to know is that the clarity that has not yet been conveyed to me at least which this case is has Georgia done anything to the regulations, implementing the statute whereby it has made in-roads upon those regulations, either by adding or subtracting or making a differentiation in the practical enforcement of what the Secretary has done and was authorized to do.
Now, could you keep those two separate and then tell us what it is we have before us (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Because you have the first class, it is definable.
You ought to be able to tell us exactly --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: You have -- before --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- this is what the regulation said and Georgia is trying to take something away from it or add something to it.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: You have before you both questions?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Or added a time though don't make (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Now, where is that, the question of conflict?

It is the position the Government that the geography does not make any difference in the typing of tobacco, that tobacco grown across the Savannah River in South Carolina, if it has the same characteristics as Type 14 (Voice Overlap) should have is Type 14 tobacco.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap) if I may cut in, has Georgia negated that in a slightness degree --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: The answer is yes.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- but Georgia denied whereas they're typing 14 to stop then its ingredients and characteristics by the Secretary is not Type 14.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: They have said that only tobacco grown in Georgia, Florida and Alabama can be Type 14.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, if you're right about that, you don't have to worry about the second classification.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Well, that's -- that's what I'm trying to argue.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well now, before you leave it, here's a language it seems just lay one of this long side or the other, what the federal regulation says this Type 14 is the fact of produce principally in, the Southern side of Georgia to some extent further than Alabama.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: What the State regulation says is that Type 14 is that which is loosely or grown in the traditional loosely area which consist of the State of Georgia and part of Alabama.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's right.
Now, face of -- on the face of -- and may if I point out Your Honor that there is a -- that his works cumbrously.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, (Voice Overlap), why did you get the second (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Well, if you don't agree with me on the first then we get to the second. [Attempt to Laughter]

But if I may point this out that the -- the conflict works conversely also that the tobacco that is grown in Georgia, that the federal inspector would say that this is type 13 or 12 or 11, that the Georgia statute would say, “No, it's grown in Georgia and therefore it's, the 14.”

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now, Mr. Cohn, to disagree with you, imply that the language is so confused or that Georgia determination either by an appropriate organ of the administration or in practice has negated on what you said, otherwise, you ought to be able to read and say, “Yes, this is an addition or a subtraction” whichever it maybe.
You seem to think this is a matter of controversy whether you're right on your first proposition.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Well, my -- my

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Why it could have been --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- opponents controvert it.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I know.
I'm not talking about lawyer's arguments.
I'm talking about the materials by which a court must judge.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Well, the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That ought to be susceptible of more or less easy determination.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: In my mind Your Honor, it is.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That is all --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: In my mind, it's a matter of reading the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Tell me what I should read in order to conclude that you're right?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: You read --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Just tell me what I should read?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: The definition of Type 14 in the federal --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Where is that?
Just give me page --

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: (Inaudible), page 8.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Page 8.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: The top of the page.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Alright (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Read that in light of the definition of types on 6 of my brief.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: What else?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: And read in the --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: The Georgia statute.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: The Georgia statute, the Georgia -- the definition of 14 which I will find for you in just a moment.
It's in Section 1 for the statute back in the appendix that I know.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do the law court have any trouble in reading it the way you read it.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Page 9.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Pardon?

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Does District Court have any trouble in reading it they way you read it?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: No sir.
No trouble whatsoever.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Language must be singularly optative.
We can quarrel whether -- the Government says that two statutes are linguistically in conflict, they're not in conflict.
That -- that -- that doesn't require Solomon or just any of the desire, does it?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: The Government says that it is a conflict Your Honor and -- and we -- we submit on that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I don't care what the Government says.
Are the materials there to justify what it says?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: In my opinion, yes Your Honor.
May I point out one more thing?
I know my time has expired.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, you may (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That it maybe as Mr. Harrison has contended here that there is a reason to draw certain geographic lines because the nicotine content or chemical content or what have you.
I'm -- I'm not arguing that.
I'm not a chemist.
I'm not an expert on that, but there is a re-course open to the Georgia interest.

If they wish that these factors to be taken into consideration in the federal standards, they can go to the Sector of Agriculture under the ruling and proceedings, present their evidence and ask for the classification that they contend should be made.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Isn't the converse of that true?

Couldn't the Secretary tomorrow, whatever we decide, describe -- re-describe Type 14, as has been his practice to include South and North Carolina, and say principally grown in Alabama, North Alabama, Georgia, Florida, North and South Carolina?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Your Honor --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: (Inaudible) wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: He believes he has done that --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I understand that.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: -- but he can -- and make it the explicit if the -- the Court rules, otherwise it's not Georgia.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I mean do you think it would destroy the -- I frankly have difficulty at this time in seeing that he hadn't described it as -- as grown in those three States.

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Your Honor, you have --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I don't understand why he wanted to put other definitions (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: You have within the other definitions.
You have other types and other classes of tobacco that are grown elsewhere, that where -- would also be grown in other States.
It is -- why did you --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: But why did he construe it by putting those names and leaving the impression that it was only grown in those places?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I can't answer that Your Honor.
May I point out also that if what the Georgia interests are, they're complaining about is that the inspectors have not been properly enforcing the federal regulations.
Now, that is one thing they can bring up in their jurisdictional statement in this -- in this Court which they have not renewed in their -- their brief.
But again, they have an appeal procedure open to them to the Secretary of Agriculture.
They are not right in our view in running to the State of Georgia to intercede itself between a tobacco --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How long has this case been (Voice Overlap)?
How long has this case been litigated?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Jul -- well, you mean in this Court or?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Why hasn't the Secretary of Agriculture, whoever handles this corrected this plainly ambiguous statement?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: When you say it means one thing in the language indicates to me, it means another.
Why hasn't he corrected it so?
Why bring it up here instead of there?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I do not know Your Honor.
I -- I believe that -- he believes that it's not ambiguous.
That's all I can say.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: He believes there's no ambiguity?

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: That's right Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Do you back (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: sherman_l_cohn
turn.label: Mr. Sherman L. Cohn
turn.text: I do sir.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Groover, you may have five minutes.
Actually, Mr. Groover, that was time we've taken --

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you sir.

Mr. Chief Justice, Your Honors, let me say at the outset that if the federal inspector had classified the South Carolina and North Carolina tobacco as Type 14 and was dust-free and was precluded under the Georgia Act from having a white tag place their own, we have no case.
We cannot conflict with the Federal Government and with duly authorize the regulations all with the statute and we recognize it, but we say there is no conflict.

Let's keep in mind that the very definition that is described to Type 14 tobacco and may I say at the outset I hope the Court will keep firmly in mind that there is a difference between type and between grades.
A type is a broad general classification with that, we have adopted a -- the State of Georgia has adopted the federal government's definition.
There is absolutely no effort on the part of the State of Georgia in its acts or otherwise, to tamper with, change or in anyway communicate grade.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: Grade is merely a subdivision type?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Grade is a subdivision of type Your Honor and grade as said by Mr. Durben is the place where the -- where price is determined.
It's just like the difference between a Kansas City State Prime and a St. Louis Missouri State Prime.

turn.speaker: william_o_douglas
turn.label: Justice William O. Douglas
turn.text: But how can you say there's not a conflict when the regulation says that Type 14 shall be made regardless of geographical or --

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: I'm saying Your Honor that that's supposing the possibility of a conflict and we have here a record before this Court in which there is not one iota of evidence to -- in the infirmity and indeed if the evidence is in the contrary that none of this tobacco that was brought down there, even on the 29.1096, the broad general classification would have or was classified as Type 14.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you mean the Secretary couldn't classify in the Type 14?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir.
He could classify there's Type 14 Your Honor but he has not done so and -- and the complainants themselves in their complaint said that there're all be inspector.
The Secretary's agent did was to grade the tobacco, not make any classifications.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But then do you -- and you would -- do agree or do you agree I just have a slight to ask confliction and make confession that -- but you suggested that there is a conflict between the regulation and Section 1 of your statute.

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: No sir.
I say, there is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Under the language, I'm not talking about what was done under the lines but that there is a collision between the Secretary who defines Type 14 both not exclusively, geographically but also characteristics of tobacco outside of those -- that territory and the restrictive geographic provision of Section 1.

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: No sir, I do not make --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: (Voice Overlap)

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: -- there is a conflict because he then proceeds himself to define it or based on geography alone.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Now where is that?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: That's on the page 8 of the Government's brief.
He says that Type 14 and incidentally, the general broad, general classification is CFR 29.1096.
This is 29.1100 which follow.

Type 14 is, and this is Secretary's definition, that type of flue-cured tobacco commonly known as Southern Flue-cured or New Belt of Georgia, Florida and Alabama produced principally in the Southern section of Georgia and if I may interpolate, produced to some extent in Florida and Alabama.
Now, it seems to me that that absolutely excludes under the present pending definition.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well, no, principally to me means principally.

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, sir but if you don't --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And then if there's minor situations where it also exists.

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: And if said -- say included those minor situations, Florida and Alabama and since in this record, if Your Honor please, defendant's exhibit one shows a map promulgated and it's identified as the defendant's exhibit one shows a map which outlines the various types and in this map it show -- itself shows that which has been described as an official determination of the Secretary of Agriculture shows that the Type 14 is grown only in Georgia, Florida and Alabama.

Now, I do admit sir that there is the possibility that a man across the Savannah River, right across could grow Type 14 tobacco and that the Secretary on the 10.96 might subsequently could classify it as Type 14, but if this Court said in (Inaudible) against the United States, we've got a set of concrete facts here that Secretary has identified it as Georgia, Florida and Alabama.
The Secretary, and there's no evidence here that there is any other possibility or if indeed that person is not now before this Court.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Has the Secretary himself interpreted his definition of Type 14 to include tobacco grown outside of these three States?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Not so -- according to his official publication, defendant's exhibit one, which is a map shown in the area, not according to the witness.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In what -- in what type of Carolina tobacco fall?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: They fall in 13, 12 and 11.
It goes up to the line.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Do you mean that the record show that he himself has -- has shoved, has pigeonhole Carolina tobacco into those other types.

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir, yes sir.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What -- what, where is that?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: That, Your Honor, the defendant's exhibit one was not printed in record.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And then how can we tell?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There's something so vital (Voice overlap) is not in the record.

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Is it in the files of the Court here?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Yes sir, which I have in my hand --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Just was not printed.

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: It was just not printed.
It was sent up, yes sir.
And also in page 125 of the record --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Groover, how does the Secretary treat the Carolina so called number 14, Type 14 tobacco in his marketing reports?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: How does he treat it Your Honor?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: It is called type 13 or the type 12.
There is no Carolina type 14 tobacco under the Secretary‘s regulation.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And -- and so he solely reports in his daily or weekly reports?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Now, that's my understanding Your Honor.
I'm certain that's true but I don't --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes, but I --

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: -- make some statement.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Is there evidence to the contrary?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: No sir.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What was that page of the -- point of the record that you referring too besides exhibit one?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: Page 125 Your Honor.

It's a testimony of an employee of the Department of Agriculture, Tobacco Division, in which she identified this Court's record which was not printed and said that it's an official publi -- publication and then I interpret it is to be in the official determination.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Who is this gentleman?

turn.speaker: denmark_groover_jr
turn.label: Mr. Denmark Groover, Jr.
turn.text: This is the gentleman who works in the Tobacco Division of the Department of Agriculture Your Honor who sat in as the record reveals on the drawing of the Georgia Act and who incidentally after the passage of the Georgia Act as the record reveals had the Secretary put the last of Secretary was put in to effect in Florida exactly the same thing to put blue and white tags on tobacco grown in those areas.

On page – the very complaint here shows that we are dealing with a sub -- that counsel or the Appellants, appellees and counsel to the Government are dealing with the proposition that possibly Georgia could at some future take be in conflict with the federal definition and if someone keep up and was excluded.
